TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Placed an A-line.  Patient has been diuresing well to Lasix drip and is
   now on nasal cannula, BP being supported with Levophed.  CEs peaked at
   CK: 289  MB: 32  MBI: 11.1  Trop-T: 2.29.  But patient had chest
   tightness again after this peak and enzymes will be recycled.  Question
   of isolated ST elevation in lead V2.  Lactate continues to rise
   2.8->3.6->3.9 despite being on Levophed.  Anion gap continues to widen
   18->20, CBC with 91% PMN.  Blood and urine cx pending.  CXR ordered.
   Low Mag and calcium repleted.
   -@2100-> patient 2300cc negative for the day on lasix 5mg/hr IV drip
   and levophed.  CXR improved and requiring 6L nasal cannula to maintain
   sats.  However, requiring increased levo to maintain BP so lasix drip
   decreased to 3mg/hr for target diuresis of 75-100cc/hr so that levo can
   also be titrated down.
   -@2200-> CXR reviewed with radiology and it was felt that she may have
   a RLL PNA.  Empiric coverage with vanco and levaquin was started.
   Diuresis was stopped as patient is potentially septic.
   -@1AM-> Patient had a 2 minute run of SVT and her pressures dropped to
   50s-60s systolic.  It broke spontaneously and then recurred for about a
   minute with a similar BP drop.  EKG obtained.  Patient was
   asymptomatic.  This happened as levophed was being titrated down
   because lasix drop was shut off.  BP after event 70s-80s despite
   increased levophed.  Patient bolused 250cc NS. Continues to
   periodically go into and out of SVT with BP going as low as 40s
   systolic.
   -@230AM-> Patient taken off levophed and switched to neosynephrine.
   She has no longer had any runs of SVT following this change.
   Allergies:
   Bactrim Ds (Oral) (Sulfamethoxazole/Trimethoprim)
   tongue swelling
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2148-8-17**] 11:41 PM
   Levofloxacin - [**2148-8-18**] 12:57 AM
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 650 units/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2148-8-17**] 09:30 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2148-8-18**] 05:39 AM

   WBC

   Hct

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:/52.0/, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:230/21/1.56,
   Lactic Acid:3.3 mmol/L, Ca++:7.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:6.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 presenting with nausea and
   volume overload, now with + CEs and ?ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes positive, EKG showing ? ST
   elevation in leads V1-V3 --> DDX includes strain vs. acute plaque
   rupture. First set of CEs CK 191, MB 19, (MBI 9.9), Trop 1.51
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Will give metoprolol 6.25 [**Hospital1 **] and continue
   - Cont Statin
   - Turn off heparin gtt today
   - Plavix 600mg PO on admission
   - follow ECG
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - Peak  enzymes CK=289, MB=32, MBI=11.1, troponin=2.29; indicative of a
   small cardiac event
   - A-line placed [**8-17**] to better monitor blood pressure
   .
   # PUMP: LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
   systolic function normal on [**2147-12-28**] echo (LVEF >55%). Despite this,
   patient presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and
   CXR) in setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient
   states that she has not received this much volume during her visits
   before. Of note, in [**2147-8-28**], in setting of STEMI, patient had EF of
   40%.
   - Echo on admission shows global hypokinesis and estimated EF=25%, will
   need repeat ECHO tomorrow to re-evaluate cardiac function
   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia and runs of SVT overnight on levophed.
   - no SVT since levophed was weaned off and neosynephrine started
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 17 and lactate 3.  Likely related to poor
   forward flow in setting of volume overload and CHF exacerbation.
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Pneumonia- RLL consolidation on CXR, will start vanc/levo day 1=[**8-17**].
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Looks
   like mostly yeast at this point.
   - UCx pending
   .
   # Electrolyte abnormalities- low calcium, high phosphate, low
   potassium.  Continue to monitor and replete PRN
   .
   # Acute renal failure - baseline Cr 0.8, current value 1.5.  Suspect
   pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 Check a TSH. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .
   CODE: full, confirmed with patient and daughter
   .
   COMM: with patient, daughter
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Indwelling Port (PortaCath) - [**2148-8-17**] 04:52 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2148-8-17**] 07:00 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2148-8-17**] 04:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, an 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, presented with nausea and volume overload, now with positive cardiac enzymes and possible ST elevation in leads V1-V3. She has been receiving treatment for cardiac enzymes, including ASA, metoprolol, and statin. The patient's cardiac enzymes have peaked, with CK: 289, MB: 32, MBI: 11.1, and troponin: 2.29, indicating a small cardiac event.

The patient has been experiencing tachycardia, runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) overnight, and has required neosynephrine for blood pressure support. Her lactate levels have continued to rise, and her anion gap has widened. She has been diagnosed with acute kidney injury, hypothyroidism, metastatic bladder cancer, and osteoporosis.

The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) has shown a possible right lower lobe pneumonia, and she has been started on empiric coverage with vancomycin and levofloxacin. Her urine culture is pending.

The patient's blood and urine cultures are pending, and her complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 8.4 K/uL, with 91% polymorphonuclear cells (PMNs). Her electrolyte levels are abnormal, with low calcium, high phosphate, and low potassium.

The patient's cardiac function is compromised, with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 25% on admission, and she has been diagnosed with acute heart failure exacerbation.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, metastatic bladder cancer, and osteoporosis. She has received treatment for her cardiac condition, including thrombectomy and stenting, and has a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: Prolonged QT interval, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest due to her compromised cardiac function and the use of medications such as levophed and neosynephrine.
2. Respiratory complications: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her compromised respiratory function and the use of a nasal cannula.
3. Renal complications: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances due to her compromised renal function and the use of diuretics such as furosemide.
4. Infectious complications: Urinary tract infection, pneumonia, and bloodstream infection due to her compromised immune system and the use of invasive devices such as central lines and urinary catheters.
5. Metabolic complications: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia due to her compromised cardiac function and the use of medications such as diuretics and vasopressors.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: Gastrointestinal bleeding, nausea, and vomiting due to her compromised cardiac function and the use of medications such as heparin and warfarin.

In summary, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes positive, EKG showing ? ST
   elevation in leads V1-V3 --> DDX includes strain vs. acute plaque
   rupture. First set of CEs CK 191, MB 19, (MBI 9.9), Trop 1.51
   - ASA 325mg PO

   - Plavix 600mg PO on admission
   - follow ECG
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - Peak  enzymes CK=289, MB=32, MBI=11.1, troponin=2.29; indicative of a
   small cardiac event
   - A-line placed [**8-17**] to better monitor blood pressure
   .

   systolic function normal on [**2147-12-28**] echo (LVEF >55%). Despite this,

   CXR) in setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient
   states that she has not received this much volume during her visits
   before. Of note, in [**2147-8-28**], in setting of STEMI, patient had EF of

   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today

 Check a TSH. Continue home dose synthroid.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Acute coronary syndrome with elevated cardiac enzymes (CK: 289, MB: 32, MBI: 11.1, troponin: 2.29) indicating a small cardiac event.
	* Possible strain vs. acute plaque rupture, with ST elevation in leads V1-V3 on EKG.
	* Acute heart failure exacerbation, with decreased ejection fraction (EF) on echocardiogram.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia, with RLL consolidation on CXR, and empiric coverage with vancomycin and levofloxacin.
	* Possible respiratory distress, with decreased breath sounds at the right base on physical examination.
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute renal failure, with increasing creatinine levels (baseline 0.8, current 1.5) and a high anion gap.
	* Possible pre-renal etiology, given the BUN/Cr ratio and physical examination.
4. Electrolyte complications:
	* Hyponatremia, likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting of CHF exacerbation.
	* Metabolic acidosis, with bicarbonate 17 and lactate 3, likely related to poor forward flow in setting of volume overload and CHF exacerbation.
	* Electrolyte abnormalities, including low calcium, high phosphate, and low potassium, which need to be monitored and repleted as needed.
5. Infectious complications:
	* Possible urinary tract infection, with > 50 WBC and moderate leukocytes on urinalysis, and UCx pending.
	* Possible sepsis, given the rising lactate levels and empiric coverage with vancomycin and levofloxacin.
6. Hemodynamic complications:
	* Hypotension, requiring support with Levophed and neosynephrine.
	* Possible cardiac arrhythmias, including runs of SVT, which responded to weaning off Levophed and starting neosynephrine.
7. Other complications:
	* Possible gastrointestinal bleeding, given the presence of a nasogastric tube and the patient's history of bleeding disorders.
	* Possible surgical complications, given the patient's history of metastatic bladder cancer and previous surgeries.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old female who presented with anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2, and is now experiencing CHF exacerbation. The patient's condition is complicated by several factors:

1. **Cardiac Enzymes**: The patient's cardiac enzymes (CK, MB, and Trop-T) are elevated, indicating a small cardiac event. The peak enzymes suggest a small cardiac event, which may be related to strain or acute plaque rupture.
2. **Acute Kidney Injury**: The patient has developed acute kidney injury, which may be related to pre-renal etiology given the BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
3. **Electrolyte Abnormalities**: The patient has low calcium, high phosphate, and low potassium levels, which may be related to CHF exacerbation and acute kidney injury.
4. **Hyponatremia**: The patient has hyponatremia, which is likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in the setting of CHF exacerbation.
5. **Metabolic Acidosis**: The patient has metabolic acidosis, which is likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of volume overload and CHF exacerbation.
6. **Pneumonia**: The patient has RLL consolidation on CXR, which may be related to pneumonia.
7. **Urinary Tract Infection**: The patient has a urinary tract infection, which may be related to the indwelling urinary catheter.
8. **Hypothyroidism**: The patient has hypothyroidism, which may be related to her medical history.
9. **Metastatic Bladder Cancer**: The patient has metastatic bladder cancer, which may be related to her recent treatment with Gemzar/Cisplatin.

The patient's medical complications and comorbidities make her condition challenging to manage. The patient's tachycardia and runs of SVT overnight on levophed are concerning, and the decision to wean off levophed and switch to neosynephrine was likely made to address this issue.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. **Cardiac Enzyme Monitoring**: The patient's cardiac enzymes will be monitored to assess the extent of the cardiac event.
2. **Diuresis**: The patient will continue to receive diuresis to manage CHF exacerbation and acute kidney injury.
3. **Electrolyte Repletion**: The patient's electrolyte abnormalities will be monitored and repleted as needed.
4. **Antibiotic Therapy**: The patient will receive antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and urinary tract infection.
5. **Hypothyroidism Management**: The patient's hypothyroidism will be managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
6. **Pain Management**: The patient's pain will be managed with analgesics as needed.

The patient's prognosis is uncertain, and her condition will require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 presenting with nausea and

   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes positive, EKG showing ? ST
   elevation in leads V1-V3 --> DDX includes strain vs. acute plaque
   rupture. First set of CEs CK 191, MB 19, (MBI 9.9), Trop 1.51
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Hold B-Blocker given decreased contractility and start low dose
   dopamine to support pressure, may need levophed as well
   - Cont Statin, start morphine to ease work of breathing
   - IV heparin gtt
   - Plavix 600mg PO x 1
   - follow ECG
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - Follow-up enzymes CK=289, MB=32, MBI=11.1, troponin=2.29;  patient
   may need intubation for cath when more clinically stable and diuresed
   - Will need a-line to better monitor blood pressure
   .
   # PUMP: LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
   systolic function normal on [**2147-12-28**] echo (LVEF >55%). Despite this,
   patient presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and
   CXR) in setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient
   states that she has not received this much volume during her visits
   before. Of note, in [**2147-8-28**], in setting of STEMI, patient had EF of
   40%.
   - Repeat echo in AM shows global hypokinesis and estimated EF=25%
   - continue aggressive diuresis; given additional 40 mg IV dose, patient
   did not diurese and will need intubation for cath
   - will give 100mg Lasix IV and judge response before starting Lasix
   drip
   - Start morphine
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia currently, likely in setting of ACS.
   - will treat for underlying ACS and monitor for improvement
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - check urine lytes
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 17 and lactate 3.  Likely related to poor
   forward flow in setting of volume overload and CHF exacerbation.
   - continue diuresis as above
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes.
   - UCx pending
   - will defer Abx for now given hx of radiation cystitis
   .
   # Acute renal failure - baseline Cr 0.8, current value 1.4.  Suspect
   pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - urine lytes and eos
   - trend UOP and Cr, anticipate improvement with diuresis
   .
   # h/o htn - currently hypotensive and being diuresed for CHF
   exacerbation.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism - continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old female with a history of anterior ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and is currently presenting with nausea, volume overload, and cardiac enzymes (CEs) positive. The patient has been diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and is being treated with antiplatelet agents, statin, and morphine.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.9C (98.5F)
* Heart rate: 94 bpm (sinus tachycardia)
* Blood pressure: 97/61 mmHg (hypotensive)
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute (normal)
* Oxygen saturation: 97% (on nasal cannula)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Cardiac enzymes: CK 289, MB 32, MBI 11.1, Troponin-T 2.29
* Electrolytes: Na+ 132 mmol/L, K+ 3.3 mmol/L, Cl- 96 mmol/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 14.2 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.6 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.3 mmol/L

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Mild respiratory distress
* JVP 14 cm
* Diffuse rales in both lungs
* Tachycardic with regular rhythm
* Soft, non-tender, non-distended abdomen
* 1+ edema in both lower extremities
* Warm and distal pulses in both lower extremities

The patient's medical history is significant for:

* Anterior STEMI with 2-vessel coronary artery disease (CAD)
* Thrombectomy and balloon angioplasty (BMS) to proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery
* Hypothyroidism
* Metastatic bladder cancer
* Distant history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
* Osteoporosis
* Hypercholesterolemia

The patient's current medications include:

* Aspirin 325 mg PO daily
* Plavix 600 mg PO once
* Statin (simvastatin) 80 mg daily
* Fosamax (alendronate) 70 mg weekly
* Synthroid (levothyroxine) 0.05 mg daily
* Gemzar (gemcitabine) and Cisplatin for metastatic bladder cancer

The patient's current diagnosis is:

* Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)
* Cardiac tamponade
* Hyponatremia
* Metabolic acidosis
* Acute renal failure
* Urinary tract infection (UTI)
* Hypothyroidism
* Osteoporosis
* Hypercholesterolemia

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac tamponade
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Infection
* Sepsis
* Metabolic acidosis
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Aggressive diuresis with furosemide (Lasix)
* Supportive care with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as needed
* Monitoring of cardiac enzymes and troponin-T levels
* Echocardiogram to assess left ventricular function
* Urine lytes and eosinophils to assess kidney function
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels to assess kidney function
* Lactic acid levels to assess metabolic acidosis
* Electrolyte levels to assess for hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia
* Antibiotic therapy for UTI
* Pain management with morphine
* Cardiac rhythm monitoring
* Respiratory monitoring
* Neurological monitoring
* Blood pressure monitoring
* Oxygen saturation monitoring

   .

   - UCx pending

   potassium.  Continue to monitor and replete PRN
   .

   pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c

 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives

   # hypothyroidism
 Check a TSH. Continue home dose synthroid.

   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old female who presented to the ICU with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2, and is now experiencing nausea and volume overload. She has positive cardiac enzymes, and her EKG shows possible ST elevation in leads V1-V3. She has been diagnosed with acute CHF exacerbation and is receiving treatment for pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and acute kidney injury. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, metastatic bladder cancer, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

The patient has been experiencing runs of SVT overnight, which have resolved with the use of levophed and neosynephrine. She is receiving treatment for hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte abnormalities. Her current vital signs are: temperature 37.3C, heart rate 97 bpm, blood pressure 112/68 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 96%.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: Given the patient's history of anterior STEMI and acute CHF exacerbation, there is a risk of further cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's pneumonia and acute kidney injury may lead to respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further complications, such as chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's urinary tract infection and pneumonia may lead to further infectious complications, such as sepsis or septic shock.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte abnormalities may lead to further metabolic complications, such as seizures or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and requirement for neosynephrine may lead to further hemodynamic instability, such as shock or cardiac arrest.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of metastatic bladder cancer and previous chemotherapy may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and previous chemotherapy may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or cognitive impairment.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and treatment response to prevent or manage potential medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a history of SVT, tachycardia, and hypotension. They have a positive blood culture growing gram-negative rods, which is being treated with levo and vanc antibiotics. The patient is experiencing mild respiratory distress, diffuse rales, and tachycardia. They have a soft, non-tender abdomen, and their extremities show 1+ edema. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, troponin-T, and lactic acid levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's gram-negative sepsis could lead to septic shock, which requires prompt recognition and management.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's respiratory distress and positive blood culture increase the risk of developing VAP, which can worsen respiratory function and increase mortality.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponin-T levels suggest cardiac involvement, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
4. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and potential sepsis increase the risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxia may progress to respiratory failure, requiring invasive mechanical ventilation.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's antibiotic use and potential sepsis increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hemorrhagic shock.
7. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's immobility and potential sepsis increase the risk of developing DVT and PE, which can lead to life-threatening complications.
8. Central Nervous System (CNS) Complications: The patient's sepsis and potential antibiotic use may lead to CNS complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, or meningitis.
9. Infection-Related Complications: The patient's positive blood culture and antibiotic use increase the risk of developing infection-related complications, such as sepsis, abscesses, or osteomyelitis.

   Assessment and Plan
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now p/w
   NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB
   32, MB index 11.2 and EKG showed ? ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   Patient likely had a cardiac event/NSTEMI which is likely from acute
   plaque rupture vs. (less likely) demand ischemia.
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   - Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - Simvastatin 80 mg daily
   - repeat EKG today
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - consider cardiac catheterization
   .
   # PUMP: newly reduced EF 15-20% on admission echo, showing global
   hypokinesis.  DDX for newly reduced EF includes NSTEMI (likely) vs.
   (less likely) sepsis (given positive blood cx from ED).  Previous echo
   in [**2147-12-28**] showed LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and
   regional/global systolic function normal (LVEF >55).  Patient
   presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and CXR) in
   setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient states that
   she has not received this much volume during her visits before.
   - ECHO today to evaluate if EF is improving
   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today
   - continue A line to monitor BP
   - now off lasix gtt
   - neosynephrine gtt to maintain MAPs (currently 0.5), titrate today to
   SBP 90s-100s
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia with two runs of SVT overnight (one while
   on levo, other while on neo).
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - repeat EKG today
   - consult EP if she continues to go into SVT today
   .
   # SIRS/bacteremia
 overnight, blood cx from ED positive for GNRs.
   Currently on vanc/levo day 3 for RLL pneumonia.
   - stop vanc today.  Continue levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives.
   - repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
   - has been afebrile overnight, still with left shift
   - f/u cultures for 48hrs
   .
   #  Pneumonia- RLL consolidation on CXR
   -          on vanc/levo day 1=[**8-17**] (day 3 today)
   -          -stop vanc today
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   - goal I/O even to -500 cc per day
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 19, lactate trending down, likely related
   to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.  Previous acidosis
   likely related to poor forward flow in setting of volume overload/CHF
   exacerbation as well as SIRS/sepsis.
   - trend lactate and SvO2
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Looks
   like mostly yeast at this point.
   -          UCx pending from [**8-19**]
   .
   # Acute renal failure
 resolving.  baseline Cr 0.8, current value
   1.3.  Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   -          now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   -          change foley today
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypocalcemia- on calcium gtt
   -monitor free ionized calcium
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now presenting with NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis. She has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of pneumonia, bacteremia, and acute kidney injury. She has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and levofloxacin, and has had a cardiac catheterization.

The patient has had two runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) overnight, which have resolved spontaneously. She has also had a positive blood culture from the ED, growing GNRs. She has been treated with metoprolol and ativan, and has been given a diagnosis of sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 97 beats per minute, blood pressure of 112/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 115 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 11.7 g/dL, and a platelet count of 612 x 10^9/L. Her creatinine level is 1.3 mg/dL, and her lactate level is 1.5 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture and elevated lactate level suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia can worsen her respiratory status and increase her risk of complications, such as respiratory failure and sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output suggest acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and reduced EF increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen her organ perfusion and increase her risk of complications, such as organ failure and death.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's elevated blood glucose level can worsen her metabolic status and increase her risk of complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.
7. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia can worsen her cardiac status and increase her risk of complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
8. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's hypercholesterolemia can increase her risk of cardiovascular disease and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to assess for signs of sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury.
3. Adjust the patient's cardiac medications as needed to manage her cardiac status.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose level and adjust her insulin regimen as needed to manage her hyperglycemia.
5. Monitor the patient's calcium level and adjust her calcium supplements as needed to manage her hypocalcemia.
6. Consider a cardiac catheterization to assess the patient's coronary arteries and plan further management.
7. Consider a kidney biopsy to assess the patient's kidney function and plan further management.
8. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust her sedation regimen as needed to manage her delirium.

   Assessment and Plan
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now p/w
   NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB
   32, MB index 11.2 and EKG showed ? ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   Patient likely had a cardiac event/NSTEMI which is likely from acute
   plaque rupture vs. (less likely) demand ischemia.
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   - Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - Simvastatin 80 mg daily
   - repeat EKG today
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - consider cardiac catheterization
   .
   # PUMP: newly reduced EF 15-20% on admission echo, showing global
   hypokinesis.  DDX for newly reduced EF includes NSTEMI (likely) vs.
   (less likely) sepsis (given positive blood cx from ED).  Previous echo
   in [**2147-12-28**] showed LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and
   regional/global systolic function normal (LVEF >55).  Patient
   presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and CXR) in
   setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient states that
   she has not received this much volume during her visits before.
   - ECHO today to evaluate if EF is improving
   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today
   - continue A line to monitor BP
   - now off lasix gtt
   - neosynephrine gtt to maintain MAPs (currently 0.5), titrate today to
   SBP 90s-100s
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia with two runs of SVT overnight (one while
   on levo, other while on neo).
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - repeat EKG today
   - consult EP if she continues to go into SVT today
   .
   # SIRS/bacteremia
 overnight, blood cx from ED positive for GNRs.
   Currently on vanc/levo day 3 for RLL pneumonia.
   - stop vanc today.  Continue levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives.
   - repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
   - has been afebrile overnight, still with left shift
   - f/u cultures for 48hrs
   .
   #  Pneumonia- RLL consolidation on CXR
   -          on vanc/levo day 1=[**8-17**] (day 3 today)
   -          -stop vanc today
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   - goal I/O even to -500 cc per day
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 19, lactate trending down, likely related
   to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.  Previous acidosis
   likely related to poor forward flow in setting of volume overload/CHF
   exacerbation as well as SIRS/sepsis.
   - trend lactate and SvO2
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Looks
   like mostly yeast at this point.
   -          UCx pending from [**8-19**]
   .
   # Acute renal failure
 resolving.  baseline Cr 0.8, current value
   1.3.  Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   -          now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   -          change foley today
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypocalcemia- on calcium gtt
   -monitor free ionized calcium
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .
   CODE: full, confirmed with patient and daughter
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* NSTEMI: The patient's cardiac enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB 32, and MB index 11.2, indicating a cardiac event. The patient likely had a cardiac event/NSTEMI, which is likely from acute plaque rupture vs. demand ischemia.
	* Reduced EF: The patient's ejection fraction is newly reduced to 15-20% on admission echo, showing global hypokinesis. This may indicate cardiac dysfunction.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia: The patient has RLL consolidation on CXR, and is currently on vanc/levo day 1. Stopping vanc today and continuing levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives.
	* Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 96%, but may be at risk for respiratory failure due to pneumonia and cardiac complications.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute renal failure: The patient's baseline Cr was 0.8, and current value is 1.3. Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam. Improving since Lasix drip discontinuation.
4. Infectious Complications:
	* Bacteremia: The patient's blood culture from ED was positive for GNRs. Currently on vanc/levo day 3 for RLL pneumonia. Repeat blood culture to ensure resolution of bacteremia.
	* Urinary tract infection: The patient's U/A showed > 50 WBC, mod leukocytes. Looks like mostly yeast at this point. UCx pending from [**8-19**].
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is 19 mEq/L, likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting of CHF exacerbation.
	* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's bicarb level is 19, lactate trending down, likely related to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.
6. Hemodynamic Complications:
	* Hypotension: The patient remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure support. Hold other anti-hypertensives.
7. Other Complications:
	* SIRS: The patient has SIRS/sepsis, likely related to bacteremia and pneumonia.
	* Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is 125, and may be at risk for hyperglycemia due to metabolic complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these complications from worsening.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, who presented with NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis. She had a positive blood culture from the ED, growing GNRs, and is currently on vancomycin and levofloxacin for RLL pneumonia. She has been experiencing runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) overnight, which resolved spontaneously. Her physical examination is notable for decreased breath sounds at the right base, occasional rhonchi, and 1+ edema. Her laboratory results show a WBC count of 6.1, Hct of 35.5, and Cr of 1.6.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Further cardiac events, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to the patient's history of CAD and NSTEMI.
	* Reduced cardiac output and hypotension due to the patient's reduced EF and volume overload.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia progression or development of new respiratory infections, particularly given the patient's positive blood culture and RLL consolidation on CXR.
	* Respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the patient's decreased breath sounds and occasional rhonchi.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening of existing AKI due to the patient's pre-existing renal disease and hypovolemia.
	* Fluid overload or congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation due to the patient's reduced EF and volume overload.
4. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's positive blood culture and bacteremia.
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI) progression or development of new infections, particularly given the patient's positive urine culture and mod leukocytes.
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis or worsening of existing acidosis due to the patient's reduced cardiac output and hypovolemia.
	* Hyponatremia or worsening of existing hyponatremia due to the patient's CHF exacerbation and volume overload.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and address potential medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, and now presenting with NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, and SIRS/sepsis.

The patient has had two runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) overnight, which resolved spontaneously. The patient was given 12.5 mg PO metoprolol and.5mg PO ativan, and her blood pressure remained stable between 90s-130s during these events.

The patient has a positive blood culture from the emergency department (ED) growing Gram-negative rods (GNRs) and is currently on vancomycin and levofloxacin for RLL pneumonia. The patient's blood culture was re-cultured at 0230 hours, and all cultures (blood, urine, and sputum) are pending.

The patient's physical examination is significant for decreased breath sounds at the right base, occasional rhonchi at the right lung field, and 1+ edema in the lower extremities. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3C (99.1F), heart rate of 97 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/68 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate levels. The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a troponin level of 1.56 ng/mL.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Cardiac catheterization to assess for coronary artery disease
* Continue current regimen of vancomycin and levofloxacin for RLL pneumonia
* Monitor and expect improvement with diuresis for hyponatremia
* Trend lactate and SvO2 levels for metabolic acidosis
* Continue current regimen of antihypertensives, including metoprolol and neo-synephrine
* Monitor and manage urinary tract infection
* Continue current regimen of anticoagulation and prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer
* Continue to monitor and manage the patient's condition in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac complications, such as further cardiac events or arrhythmias
* Respiratory complications, such as worsening pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Renal complications, such as worsening acute kidney injury or sepsis-induced acute kidney injury
* Infectious complications, such as bacteremia or sepsis
* Metabolic complications, such as worsening hyponatremia or metabolic acidosis
* Cardiovascular complications, such as further cardiac events or arrhythmias
* Hematological complications, such as worsening anemia or thrombocytopenia.

   Assessment and Plan
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), OTHER
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now p/w
   NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB
   32, MB index 11.2 and EKG showed ? ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   Patient likely had a cardiac event/NSTEMI which is likely from acute
   plaque rupture vs. (less likely) demand ischemia.
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   - Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - Simvastatin 80 mg daily
   - follow ECG
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - consider cardiac catheterization
   .
   # PUMP: newly reduced EF 15-20% on admission echo, showing global
   hypokinesis.  DDX for newly reduced EF includes NSTEMI (likely) vs.
   (less likely) sepsis (given positive blood cx from ED).  Previous echo
   in [**2147-12-28**] showed LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and
   regional/global systolic function normal (LVEF >55).  Patient
   presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and CXR) in
   setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient states that
   she has not received this much volume during her visits before.
   - ECHO today to evaluate if EF is improving
   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today
   - continue A line to monitor BP
   - now off lasix gtt
   - neo gtt to maintain MAPs (currently 0.5), titrate today to SBP
   90s-100s
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia with two runs of SVT overnight (one while
   on levo, other while on neo).
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   .
   # SIRS/bacteremia
 overnight, blood cx from ED positive for GNRs.
   Currently on vanc/levo day 3 for RLL pneumonia.
   - continue current regimen of vanco/levo, as patient seems to be
   clinically improving
   - repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
   - has been afebrile overnight, still with left shift
   .
   #  Pneumonia- RLL consolidation on CXR
   - on vanc/levo day 1=[**8-17**] (day 3 today)
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   - goal I/O even to -500 cc per day
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 19, lactate trending down, likely related
   to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.  Previous acidosis
   likely related to poor forward flow in setting of volume overload/CHF
   exacerbation as well as SIRS/sepsis.
   - trend lactate and SvO2
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Looks
   like mostly yeast at this point.
   - UCx pending
   .
   # Acute renal failure
 resolving.  baseline Cr 0.8, current value
   1.3.  Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .
   CODE: full, confirmed with patient and daughter
   .
   COMM: with patient, daughter
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p thrombectomy and BMS x 2 to proximal LAD. She is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of NSTEMI, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 112/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. She is on mechanical ventilation with a nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, platelet count of 612, and creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL. Her cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a troponin level of 1.56 ng/mL.

The patient's medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypercholesterolemia, hypothyroidism, metastatic bladder cancer, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. She is currently on medications including ASA, Plavix, metoprolol, and simvastatin.

The patient's current diagnosis includes NSTEMI, pneumonia, hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis, urinary tract infection, and acute renal failure. Her current treatment plan includes antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac arrest: Given her history of cardiac disease and current diagnosis of NSTEMI, the patient is at risk for cardiac arrest.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's diagnosis of pneumonia increases her risk for respiratory failure and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of SIRS and bacteremia increases her risk for sepsis and organ dysfunction.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's diagnosis of acute renal failure increases her risk for further kidney damage and potential need for dialysis.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension requires close monitoring and potential treatment with vasopressors.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's diagnosis of pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome increases her risk for respiratory failure.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's diagnosis of metabolic acidosis requires close monitoring and potential treatment with bicarbonate therapy.
8. Urinary tract infection: The patient's diagnosis of urinary tract infection requires close monitoring and potential treatment with antibiotics.
9. Hypothyroidism: The patient's diagnosis of hypothyroidism requires close monitoring and potential treatment with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
10. Osteoporosis: The patient's diagnosis of osteoporosis requires close monitoring and potential treatment with bone density therapy.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. Close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent and manage these complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is a 62-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cancer (malignant neoplasm) and coronary artery disease (CAD). Over the past 24 hours, the patient experienced two runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), both of which resolved spontaneously. The patient was given metoprolol and ativan to manage the symptoms. The patient was also paged by the microbiology lab regarding a positive blood culture from the emergency department, which grew Gram-negative rods (GNRs). The patient is currently receiving antibiotics, including levo and vanc.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 112/68 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 18 inspirations per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 96%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Septic shock: The patient's positive blood culture and elevated lactate levels suggest a high risk of septic shock.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of SVT and the use of metoprolol may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's positive blood culture and the use of antibiotics suggest a high risk of infection.
4. Bleeding: The patient's elevated platelet count and the use of anticoagulant medications may increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and the use of nephrotoxic medications may increase the risk of renal failure.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's elevated lactate levels and the use of oxygen therapy may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and the use of antibiotics may increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of cancer and the use of anticoagulant medications may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

   Assessment and Plan
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), OTHER
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 presenting with nausea and
   volume overload, now with + CEs and ?ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with known 1 vessel CAD and is s/p thrombectomy and
   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes positive, EKG showing ? ST
   elevation in leads V1-V3 --> DDX includes strain vs. acute plaque
   rupture. First set of CEs CK 191, MB 19, (MBI 9.9), Trop 1.51
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Will give metoprolol 6.25 [**Hospital1 **] and continue
   - Cont Statin
   - Turn off heparin gtt today
   - Plavix 600mg PO on admission
   - follow ECG
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - Peak  enzymes CK=289, MB=32, MBI=11.1, troponin=2.29; indicative of a
   small cardiac event
   - A-line placed [**8-17**] to better monitor blood pressure
   .
   # PUMP: LV and RV wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
   systolic function normal on [**2147-12-28**] echo (LVEF >55%). Despite this,
   patient presenting with acute CHF exacerbation (given physical exam and
   CXR) in setting of receiving 2 units of pRBC and 300 cc NS. Patient
   states that she has not received this much volume during her visits
   before. Of note, in [**2147-8-28**], in setting of STEMI, patient had EF of
   40%.
   - Echo on admission shows global hypokinesis and estimated EF=25%, will
   need repeat ECHO tomorrow to re-evaluate cardiac function
   - keep I/Os even to -500 cc as patient euvolemic today
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia and runs of SVT overnight on levophed.
   - no SVT since levophed was weaned off and neosynephrine started
   .
   # Hyponatremia - likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia in setting
   of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor and expect improvement with diuresis
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis - bicarb 17 and lactate 3.  Likely related to poor
   forward flow in setting of volume overload and CHF exacerbation.
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Pneumonia- RLL consolidation on CXR, will start vanc/levo day 1=[**8-17**].
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Looks
   like mostly yeast at this point.
   - UCx pending
   .
   # Electrolyte abnormalities- low calcium, high phosphate, low
   potassium.  Continue to monitor and replete PRN
   .
   # Acute renal failure - baseline Cr 0.8, current value 1.5.  Suspect
   pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive and requires neosynephrine for pressure
   support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 Check a TSH. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .
   CODE: full, confirmed with patient and daughter
   .
   COMM: with patient, daughter
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with ongoing ischemia and possible recurrent cardiac events.
	* Cardiac tamponade due to ongoing cardiac enzyme release and potential cardiac rupture.
	* Ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation, due to ongoing ischemia and possible electrolyte imbalance.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia, potentially worsening with ongoing respiratory failure.
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to fluid overload and possible cardiac complications.
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia, hypotension, and possible nephrotoxicity from antibiotics.
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression due to ongoing hypertension and potential nephrotoxicity.
4. Metabolic complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis due to ongoing lactic acidosis, hyperventilation, and possible electrolyte imbalance.
	* Hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypokalemia due to ongoing metabolic acidosis and possible electrolyte imbalance.
5. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis due to ongoing bacteremia and possible septic shock.
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI) due to ongoing bacteriuria and possible sepsis.
6. Hematological complications:
	* Bleeding due to ongoing thrombocytopenia and possible platelet dysfunction.
7. Electrolyte complications:
	* Hypokalemia due to ongoing diuretic therapy and possible hypomagnesemia.
	* Hypocalcemia due to ongoing metabolic acidosis and possible hypomagnesemia.

Given the patient's history of malignancy, cardiac disease, and ongoing medical conditions, it is essential to closely monitor their condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now p/w
   NSTEMI vs demand ischemia, newly reduced EF, volume overload,
   SIRS/sepsis.
   .

   stress-induced Tokotsubo cardiomyopathy given her improvement in EF and
   the pattern of hypokinesis/dyskinesis.

   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   - Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - Simvastatin 80 mg daily
   - repeat EKG today
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - no cardiac catheterization needed immediately at this time
   .

   hypokinesis, now markedly improved to 45% (on yesterday
s echo).

   prior volume overload, sepsis, etc).  Patient presented with acute CHF
   exacerbation, now diuresed and off RA.
   - back on neo this AM, attempt to wean
   - given gentle IVF overnight which seems to have improved her HR
   slightly
   - continue A line to monitor BP (goal SBP 90-100)
   - now off lasix gtt
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia with two runs of SVT overnight, resolved
   without intervention
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - repeat EKG today
   - consider EP consult for her SVT runs now that she has had them off
   pressors
   .
   # SIRS/bacteremia
 blood and urine cx from ED positive for GNRs.
   Currently on levo day 4 for RLL pneumonia.  Vanc stopped yesterday
   (after 3 days).
   - Continue levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives
   - repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
   - has been afebrile overnight, WBC decreased this AM to 2.1, [**1-29**] to
   chemo vs. improving SIRS?
   - f/u surveillance cx
   .
   #  Pneumonia - RLL consolidation on CXR
   - off vanc (completed 3 days), on levo (day 4 today)
   .
   # Hypotension
 likely related to SIRS/UTI/pneumonia/bacteremia.  Of
   note, patient
s blood pressure normally sbp 90s-100s, per patient.
   - will continue Abx regimen
   - continue A-line
   - currently off pressors/neo with sbp > 90s
   .
   # Hyponatremia
 resolved. Likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia
   in setting of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor with goal I/O even today
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis
 resolved.  Bicarb 23, lactate trending down,
   likely related to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.
   Previous acidosis likely related to poor forward flow in setting of
   volume overload/CHF exacerbation as well as SIRS/sepsis.
   - trend lactate and SvO2 if clinical picture changes
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Now
   urine cx with > 100k GNRs.
   - follow UCx from [**8-17**] for GNR ID
   .
   # Acute renal failure
 resolving.  Baseline Cr 0.8, current value
   1.3.  Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   - foley changed yesterday
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive, on low dose neo for pressure support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypocalcemia
   -          monitor free ionized calcium
   -          continue SS Ca
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .

The patient's recent events include:

* Bedside echo showing markedly improved LVEF to 45%
* Two short runs of SVT with HR to 150s, spontaneously resolved before EKG could be done, patient asymptomatic
* Weaned off neo last night, BP dropped this AM, back on neo 0.25 mcg/kg/min at 6 AM

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Tmax: 37.3C (99.1F)
* Tcurrent: 36.8C (98.3F)
* HR: 110 bpm (86-110)
* BP: 109/64 mmHg (80-122/99-107)
* RR: 21 inspirations per minute (14-26)
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 6.1 (4.8)
* Hct: 35.5 (34.3-33.5)
* Plt: 612 (596)
* Cr: 1.5 (1.5-1.5)
* TropT: 1.07
* TCO2: 20 (20-23)
* Glucose: 168 (99-107)
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 11.9/50.7/1.0, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 165/15/1.07, Lactic Acid: 1.5 mmol/L, Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.4 mg/dL, PO4: 3.4 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Cardiomyopathy, other
* Alteration in nutrition
* Bacteremia
* Cancer (malignant neoplasm), other
* Coronary artery disease (CAD, ischemic heart disease)

The patient's current treatment includes:

* ASA 325mg PO
* Plavix 75 mg daily
* Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
* Simvastatin 80 mg daily
* Repeat EKG today
* No integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
* No cardiac catheterization needed immediately at this time

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Urinary tract infection
* Hypotension
* Hyponatremia
* Metabolic acidosis
* Osteoporosis
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Hypocalcemia

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives
* Repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
* Continue A-line to monitor BP
* Continue Abx regimen
* Monitor for signs of sepsis
* Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure
* Monitor for signs of kidney injury
* Monitor for signs of metabolic acidosis

Summary:

The patient is a 81-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cardiomyopathy, other alteration in nutrition, bacteremia, and coronary artery disease. She has a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, and is currently experiencing NSTEMI vs demand ischemia. Her cardiac enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB 32, and MB index 11.2, and her EKG showed ST elevation in leads V1-V3.

The patient's 24-hour events include:

* Bedside echo reviewed, showing markedly improved LVEF to 45%
* Two short runs of SVT with HR to 150s, spontaneously resolved before EKG could be done, patient asymptomatic
* Weaned off neo last night, BP dropped this AM, back on neo 0.25 mcg/kg/min @ 6 AM

The patient's current condition is:

* Hemodynamically stable, with BP 109/64 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, and SpO2 96%
* Respiratory support with nasal cannula and ABG 7.46/28/120/23/-1
* Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at right base, occasional rhonchi right > left, and 1+ edema, warm
* Labs show WBC 6.1, Hct 35.5, Plt 612, Cr 1.5, TropT 1.07, and TCO2 20
* Microbiology results show GNR 100k in urine and blood cultures

Potential medical complications:

* Stress-induced cardiomyopathy: The patient's improved LVEF and pattern of hypokinesis/dyskinesis suggest stress-induced cardiomyopathy, which is a reversible condition.
* Bacteremia: The patient's blood and urine cultures are positive for GNRs, and she is currently on levoquin for RLL pneumonia.
* Pneumonia: The patient has RLL consolidation on CXR and is off vanc, on levoquin day 4.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is currently stable, but she has a history of hypotension and is on low-dose neo for pressure support.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia has resolved, but she is at risk for developing it again due to her CHF exacerbation and SIRS.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis has resolved, but she is at risk for developing it again due to her sepsis and poor forward flow.
* Urinary tract infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection, and her urine culture shows > 100k GNRs.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is resolving, but she is at risk for developing it again due to her pre-renal etiology and SIRS.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is well-controlled on her home dose of synthroid.
* Metastatic bladder cancer: The patient has a history of metastatic bladder cancer and has received chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
* Distant history of Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma: The patient has a history of Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma and has received chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
* Osteoporosis: The patient has osteoporosis and is on fosamax as per her home regimen.
* Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia is being monitored, and she is receiving SS Ca.
* Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has hypercholesterolemia and is on simvastatin 80 mg.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue antibiotics for bacteremia and pneumonia
* Monitor for signs of stress-induced cardiomyopathy and bacteremia
* Continue to manage her hypotension and hyponatremia
* Monitor her metabolic acidosis and lactate levels
* Follow up with urology for further evaluation and treatment of her urinary tract infection
* Continue to manage her acute renal failure and monitor for signs of worsening
* Continue to monitor her hypothyroidism and adjust her medication as needed
* Continue to manage her metastatic bladder cancer and follow up with her oncologist
* Continue to monitor her distant history of Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma and follow up with her oncologist
* Continue to manage her osteoporosis and hypercholesterolemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour follow-up in the ICU with ongoing management of cardiomyopathy, alteration in nutrition, bacteremia, and coronary artery disease. The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) has improved to 45% from the previous 30% with bedside echo. The patient experienced two short runs of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) with heart rates up to 150 beats per minute, which resolved spontaneously. The patient remains asymptomatic.

Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 109/64 mmHg. The patient is receiving prophylactic heparin sodium and has an indwelling port, arterial line, and central venous catheter in place.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 35.5 g/L, and platelet count of 612 x 10^9/L. Blood cultures are positive for gram-negative rods. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated at 1.07 ng/mL, and lactic acid level is 1.5 mmol/L.

The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen delivery, with an SpO2 of 96%. The patient's physical examination is stable, with no new abnormalities noted.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of SVT and the presence of cardiomyopathy increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Bacteremia: The patient's positive blood cultures for gram-negative rods indicate ongoing bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying cardiomyopathy and bacteremia increase the risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient develops sepsis or cardiac tamponade.
4. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential for bacteremia increase the risk of renal dysfunction.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of stress ulcer prophylaxis and the presence of bacteremia increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and bacteremia increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
7. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiomyopathy and bacteremia increase the risk of cardiac tamponade, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.

   slightly
   - continue A line to monitor BP (goal SBP 90-100)
   - now off lasix gtt
   .

   without intervention
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid

 likely related to SIRS/UTI/pneumonia/bacteremia.  Of

s blood pressure normally sbp 90s-100s, per patient.
   - will continue Abx regimen

   .

 resolved. Likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia
   in setting of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor with goal I/O even today

   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   - foley changed yesterday
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive, on low dose neo for pressure support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large

   .

   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old female with a history of anterior STEMI, s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now presenting with NSTEMI vs demand ischemia, newly reduced EF, volume overload, SIRS/sepsis.

The patient has undergone significant changes in her condition over the past 24 hours. The bedside echo review shows a markedly improved LVEF to 45%, which is consistent with resolving stress cardiomyopathy. The patient has also experienced two short runs of SVT with HR to 150s, which spontaneously resolved before EKG could be done. The patient remains asymptomatic.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/64 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 96% on nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1, hemoglobin of 35.5, and platelet count of 612. The patient's cardiac enzymes have peaked to troponin 1.07, and her CK/CKMB/Troponin-T levels are within normal limits.

The patient's urine culture shows >100k GNRs, and her blood culture is pending. The patient is currently on levofloxacin for RLL pneumonia and has completed three days of vancomycin.

The patient's physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at the right base, occasional rhonchi, and 1+ edema. The patient's abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

The patient's medications include ASA 325mg PO, Plavix 75mg daily, Metoprolol 12.5mg tid, and Simvastatin 80mg daily. The patient is also receiving gentle IVF overnight and is being monitored for hypotension.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's newly reduced EF and history of anterior STEMI make her at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's decreased breath sounds at the right base and occasional rhonchi make her at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and respiratory failure.
3. Infectious complications: The patient's urine culture shows >100k GNRs, and her blood culture is pending. The patient is at risk for sepsis, bacteremia, and other infectious complications.
4. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure and history of hypertension make her at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis make her at risk for metabolic complications such as seizures, coma, and death.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's infectious status and adjust antibiotics as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust fluids and medications as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's metabolic status and adjust medications as necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a cardiologist and/or intensivist to further evaluate and manage the patient's condition.
7. Consider performing a cardiac catheterization to further evaluate the patient's coronary arteries and potential blockages.
8. Consider performing a repeat echocardiogram to further evaluate the patient's cardiac function and potential complications.

   81F with hx of anterior STEMI s/p BMS x 2 to proximal LAD, now p/w
   NSTEMI vs demand ischemia, newly reduced EF, volume overload,
   SIRS/sepsis.
   .

   BMS x 2 to proximal LAD.  Cardiac Enzymes peaked to troponin 2.29, MB
   32, MB index 11.2 and EKG showed ? ST elevation in leads V1-V3.
   Patient likely had a cardiac event/NSTEMI which is likely
   stress-induced Tokotsubo cardiomyopathy given her improvement in EF and
   the pattern of hypokinesis/dyskinesis.
   - ASA 325mg PO
   - Plavix 75 mg daily
   - Metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - Simvastatin 80 mg daily
   - repeat EKG today
   - no integrilin and no ACEi given acute kidney injury
   - no cardiac catheterization needed immediately at this time
   .
   # PUMP: newly reduced EF 15-20% on admission echo, showing global
   hypokinesis, now markedly improved to 45% (on yesterday
s echo).
   Suspect stress-induced Tokotsubo cardiomyopathy as noted above (from
   prior volume overload, sepsis, etc).  Patient presented with acute CHF
   exacerbation, now diuresed and off RA.
   - back on neo this AM, attempt to wean
   - given gentle IVF overnight which seems to have improved her HR
   slightly
   - continue A line to monitor BP (goal SBP 90-100)
   - now off lasix gtt
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus tachycardia with two runs of SVT overnight, resolved
   without intervention
   - BP stable from 90s-130s during these events
   - on metoprolol 12.5 mg tid
   - repeat EKG today
   - consider EP consult for her SVT runs now that she has had them off
   pressors
   .
   # SIRS/bacteremia
 blood and urine cx from ED positive for GNRs.
   Currently on levo day 4 for RLL pneumonia.  Vanc stopped yesterday
   (after 3 days).
   - Continue levofloxacin to cover for gram negatives
   - repeat blood cx to ensure resolution of bacteremia
   - has been afebrile overnight, WBC decreased this AM to 2.1, [**1-29**] to
   chemo vs. improving SIRS?
   - f/u surveillance cx
   .
   #  Pneumonia - RLL consolidation on CXR
   - off vanc (completed 3 days), on levo (day 4 today)
   .
   # Hypotension
 likely related to SIRS/UTI/pneumonia/bacteremia.  Of
   note, patient
s blood pressure normally sbp 90s-100s, per patient.
   - will continue Abx regimen
   - continue A-line
   - currently on low dose neo/wean off and hydrate with gentle IVF
   .
   # Hyponatremia
 resolved. Likely related to hypervolemic hyponatremia
   in setting of CHF exacerbation.
   - monitor with goal I/O even today
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis
 resolved.  Bicarb 23, lactate trending down,
   likely related to increased forward flow and resolving sepsis.
   Previous acidosis likely related to poor forward flow in setting of
   volume overload/CHF exacerbation as well as SIRS/sepsis.
   - trend lactate and SvO2 if clinical picture changes
   .
   # Urinary tract infection - U/A showing > 50 wbc, mod leukocytes. Now
   urine cx with > 100k GNRs.
   - follow UCx from [**8-17**] for GNR ID
   .
   # Acute renal failure
 resolving.  Baseline Cr 0.8, current value
   1.3.  Suspect pre-renal etiology given BUN/Cr ratio and physical exam.
   - now improving since Lasix drip d/c
   - foley changed yesterday
   .
   # h/o htn
 Remains hypotensive, on low dose neo for pressure support.
   - hold other anti-hypertensives
   .
   # hypothyroidism
 TSH wnl. Continue home dose synthroid.
   .
   # metastatic bladder cancer - received third cycle of Gemzar/Cisplatin
   (most recent treatment [**8-15**]).  Previously received BCG therapy.
   .
   # distant hx of Non-Hodkins Lymphoma - lymphoma in [**2115**] with a large
   axillary mass, status post MOP chemotherapy and mantle radiation.
   .
   # osteoporosis - continue fosamax, as per home regimen.
   .
   # hypocalcemia
   -          monitor free ionized calcium
   -          continue SS Ca
   .
   # hypercholesterolemia - continue simvastatin 80 mg.
   .
   FEN: regular heart healthy diet
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin sc
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   .
